title: Jonathan Sarker
text:
Welcome!
Hi, I’m Jonathan. I’m a life-long learner with interests spanning from biophysics, education and machine learning. This is my personal site to share projects, interesting ideas and personal musings. Happy browsing!

title: Projects
text:
Self Learning Journey


Reflections on my (ongoing) journey of self-study






Jun 4, 2024








No matching items

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Physics

The Feynman Lectures on Physics by Richard Feynman

These volumes have a wealth of insight and beautiful exposition straight from one of greatest teachers and legends of the subject. What other physics text has the Krebs Cycle?

Principles of Quantum Mechanics by Ramamurti Shankar

With solved problems, fantastic organization and such a strong 1st chapter, this text helped me learn quantum mechanics more than any of the numerous classes I’ve taken.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Mathematics

How to Solve It by George Polya

This was an influential read that provides a general framework on solving problems not only in math, but beyond.

How to Prove It by Daniel J. Velleman

I recall stumbling through proofs before working through the first few chapters of this helpful resource.

All of Statistics by Larry Wasserman

This book has such a high range of topics and working through through many of the problems yielded long-lasting insights into graduate statistics.

Statistical Inference by George Casella and Roger Berger

This is a staple reference whenever I find myself requiring deeper insight into fundamentals.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Machine Learning

Information Theory, Inference and Learning Algorithms by David MacKay

Another amazing resource for self-study, providing insightful expositions and exercises with Bayesian inference, core information theory like entropy and machine learning’s relation to compression.

Introduction to Statistical Learning by Hastie, Tibshirani, James and Witten

This book has some nice explanations of decision trees and is accessible.

The Elements of Statistical Learning by Hastie, Tibshirani and Friedman

A well known resource and great reference for insights into machine learning.

Deep Learning for Coders with fastai & PyTorch by Jeremy Howard and Sylvain Gugger

This book had such practical bits of knowledge and insights into Pytorch and applied machine learning, by one of the greatest contributors to the machine learning community.

Natural Language Processing with Transformers by Tunstall, von Werra and Wolf

Another great practical book by contributors to the machine learning community, providing insight into the transformers architecture and library.

Effective Xgboost by Matt Harrison

A practical guide to XGBoost and integration into workflows.

Effective Data Science Infrastructure by Ville Tuulos Written by the author of the library Metaflow, this provides great insights into productive workflows in data science and expressing that in code.
Machine Learning with PyTorch and Scikit-Learn by Sebastian Raschka

This book has a nice blend of fundamentals with application, signature to the author’s insightful writings and work in general.

Designing Data-Intensive Applications by Martin Kleppmann

A great reference for studying system design.

The Kaggle Book by Banachewicz and Massaron

Filled with insights and tips in data science gleaned from Kaggle competitions.

The Kaggle Workbook by Banachewicz and Massaron

The practical counterpart to the previous book that helps build skill via code exercises.

Designing Machine Learning Systems by Chip Huyen

This was such a great book that helped me understand the bigger picture with machine learning, in the context of system design and MLOps.

AI Engineering by Chip Huyen

What the author’s first book did for ML systems, this book does for generative AI applications, providing a wide survey of important topics, in digestible bits, preserving key details and putting it all together in the final chapter.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Computer Science

Introduction to Algorithms by Cormen, Lieserson, Rivest, and Stein

Known as CLRS, it serves as a reference for classic algorithms, and is a good source of theory.


The Algorithm Design Manual by Steven Skiena

This is a text that is enjoyable to read beyond dry facts and has anecdotes from the author’s experiences in the wild along with C code implementations.

Algorithm Design by Jon Kleinberg

Somewhat in between the previous two resources, this is worth taking a look at with its different perspectives and examples.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Programming

Elements of Programming Interviews in Python by Aziz, Lee, and Prakash

My main source of interview preparation, it’s filled with difficult problems and clever coding style.

Effective Pandas by Matt Harrison

A great resource that has helped me take pride at my Pandas code and learn even more about the staple library.

Architecture Patterns with Python by Percival and Gregory

This book provided great insight with low level design and the rationale behind abstractions, providing actual code for event-driven systems.

Mastering Regular Expressions by Jeffrey Friedl

This is the resource of choice to better understand regex past just the basic level to greater commands and optimizing expressions.

Software Engineering at Google by Winters, Manshreck and Wright

This provides a new perspective on software engineering both in dimension and scale.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Economics

Basic Economics by Thomas Sowell

As someone who has never taken an economics class, the insight I gained into monetary matters while reading this book was similar to what the Feynman lectures provided for me for physics.

Healthcare Policy Issues: An Economic Perspective by Feldstein and Melnick

This book helped me better understand the US healthcare system, its players and potential reasons for its issues.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Productivity

The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People by Stephen Covey

A great read that provides a little guidance and organizing principles to living.

Atomic Habits by James Clear

The earlier one reads and implements this, the better.

So Good They Can’t Ignore You by Cal Newport

A fun read that provided inspiration to keep up with self-improvement and prioritize learning in career choices.

Deep Work by Cal Newport

This book really drives home how concentration and attention are essential to modern success and work life.


Slow Productivity by Cal Newport

Another book by Newport, this one reaffirms personal experiences I’ve had prioritizing consistency over bursts of productivity.

Range: Why Generalists Triumph in a Specialized World by David Epstein

I like being well-rounded and this book put generalists on the same pedestal we typically do for specialists.

Grit by Angela Duckworth

Inspiring stories that emphasize the importance of perseverance.

The Startup of You by Reid Hoffman

A useful read to gain a new, entrepenurial perspective on one’s self in the economy.

Zero to One by Peter Thiel

This book provided some insightful perspective on startups, innovation and monopolies.

title: Self Learning Journey
text:
Career Guides

The Effective Engineer by Edmond Lau

An interesting read on how to be a better engineer, framing it in the context of high leverage activities.

Engineer’s Survival Guide by Merih Taze

Good advice from the author’s personal experiences about navigating an SWE career.

The Staff Engineer’s Path by Tanya Reilly

I appreciated the perspective of taking the individual contributor path to the highest levels and what that looks like.

The Software Engineer’s Guidebook by Gergely Orosz

This truly is a guidebook for the SWE career path and provides so much information on what to expect at different environments, meetings and managers and time in the career.
